title: Macro the Mightiest: ET Prime Special - Part 6: How the US ‘jobs report’ impacts markets, and why
summary: Every month, the global financial engine pauses for a single data point: The US Employment Situation Summary. While ostensibly a headcount of workers, this “jobs report” has the power to shift billions in valuation within seconds in the US markets and, by extension, global markets. By deconstructing the Fed’s "dual mandate" on maximum employment and price stability we can uncover why investors treat these figures as a crystal ball for interest rates. Today, we will explore the connection between the US labour data and stock market volatility across the globe. In this series we discuss one macroeconomic factor every fortnight. Even a basic understanding will tell you when to react and when not to react to macroeconomic headlines.

title: New investor additions in markets declined by 11.6% in November (MoM): NSE Report
summary: The pace of new investor additions in the equity markets slowed in November, with growth declining 11.6 per cent month-on-month, as only 13.2 lakh new investors joined the market during the month, according to a report by the National Stock Exchange (NSE).

title: Specialty chemicals: Is the worst over, or better to own the ecosystem? 19 stocks with upside potential ranging from
summary: The chemicals sector (both specialty as well as commodity chemicals) is witnessing underlying changes at a reasonably strong pace that may soon bring it back into the limelight. These changes are focused on ensuring at least partial backward integration so that, over the medium term, dependence on Chinese imports comes down. This, however, will take time. At the same time, the chemicals sector has varied companies, each with a very different cycle. So, perhaps it's best to own a basket rather than just one or two stocks.
